AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: a small, attractive tree with nice horizontal branching
2-5” alternate leaves; smooth and green on top; hairy and bluish underside
gray to brown becoming rigid with age

Pagoda Dogwood trees do best in a cool, semi-shady area and grow well in a moist, acidic, well-drained soil. The tree is considered to be drought sensitive. The Pagoda Dogwood is particularly susceptible to a canker disease called Cryptodiaporthe. The canker fungi often infect the tree after stress. Thus, watering the tree during periods of drought is critical. The fruit of the Dogwood is popular with birds and other wildlife. The Pagoda Dogwood was once known as Pigeon-berry, referring to the fruit which was a favorite of the now extinct passenger pigeon. The name dogwood is a contraction of the word “dagwood” which goes back to the old English word “dag,” meaning dagger. Skewers or daggers were made of the extremely hard wood of the dogwood. Dogwoods have been valued for medicinal qualities. Pagoda Dogwood has been said to be helpful in treating sore eyes. Dogwood bark contains chincodine, an alternative for quinine in treating malaria. It is also said the Dogwood bark can cure mange in dogs. Chewing Dogwood twigs is said to brighten teeth. Some readers may remember the two large Pagoda Dogwoods that sat outside the west entrance to Stark Hall at WSU. A large glacier rock sat between the two attractive 25-foot tall trees before they were lost to construction. Two smaller Pagoda Dogwoods can be viewed at the northeast and northwest corners of Minné Hall.
